comments.author: Dana
comments.content: Any kind of veg noodle soup is my very favorite kind of meal.  I wouldn't have thought to use eggs - my mind naturally goes to tofu.  But this looks delicious and so artfully (and appetizingly) presented.

comments.author: Kathy
comments.content: Michael -- Have you tried the tofu from NW Tofu on Jackson & 17th? Traca turned me onto it. Amazing! Do you have a recommendation for soba noodle brands, beyond fresh noodles?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
I had lunch at NW Tofu once but didn't buy a pound to take home. I'll have
to try it. I really like the tofu from Thanh Son Tofu on 12th between Yesler
and Fir as well. It is fairly firm and yet really creamy and flavorful. They
also offer a few varieties of pre-deep-fried puffs, which are great, and
fresh soymilk. For this recipe I like the silken/soft tofu, which Thanh Son
doesn't have. Do you know if NW does? It would be great to have a local
source for that.

p.s. thanks for the tip on the Ipod repair (on twitter)

comments.author: lisaiscooking
comments.content: Wow, I'm hungry now! I'll have to keep an eye out for the Ohsawa shoyu. It sounds fantastic.

comments.author: matt
comments.content:
oh man, this looks so darn good. I am making it this week. Decided. The broth looks soo good.

can you get that rather special soy sauce locally?

Love the photo too.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Thanks Matt. The Ohsawa shoyu is available at Whole Foods for sure, and I
think maybe PCC &/or Madison Market - look in the raw foods section. I'm not
a big raw foodie, but this stuff is a winner. Congrats on the restaurant!

comments.author: Jodye
comments.content: Soba noodles are definitely a favorite around here. I love eating simple, but extremely satisfying meals like this

comments.author: Dana Zia
comments.content:
Drooooooooool. Looks perfect for a cold spring night, like tonight. I will be making this!  Thanks for the yummy post.
Dana Zia

comments.author: John - Mormon Foodie
comments.content: My mouth is watering! I like to think I can taste with my brain and, oh my. My brain is drooling too.

comments.author: Julie
comments.content: Yum!  I find myself bookmarking like every recipe on here.  Except all your restaurant reviews make me wish I had discovered your blog while I still lived in Seattle...

comments.author: The Hungry Mouse
comments.content:
Holy moly, this looks great! I'm a super carnivore, and you have me positively drooling! :D Thanks, too, for the recommendation for the shoyu. Yum!

+Jessie

comments.author: Tofu Hunter
comments.content: Looks delicious... what kind of tofu is that? Thanks!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
I don't remember what the brand was, but it was a "silken" style tofu from
whole foods. From the refrigerator case of course; those shelf-stable tofus
are not good.

comments.author: Y
comments.content: This sounds delicious, but 'crispy soba pancake' sounds even better! Looking forward to that post :)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks Julie!

comments.author: Susanna
comments.content: This looks amazing. I'm looking forward to trying it.

comments.author: Alisa@Foodista
comments.content: This looks delicious Michael!

comments.author: thepinkpeppercorn
comments.content: I love your comparison of the shoyu and parmigiano to lesser versions of the same....hehe.

comments.author: muellerb@indiana.edu
comments.content: this looks amazing! I am making it tonight!

comments.author: David Cardinez
comments.content: why the fuck would anybody put that in their mouth. go get a fucking steak you pussies.

comments.author: Janice
comments.content: I see eating meat has certainly made you a happy, enjoyable person.  I know what I usually do in my free time (and I assume you probably have an overabundance of it) is troll and lurk on blogs waiting to leave my little treats of discontent anywhere I might find an idea, or way of thinking that doesn't coexsist with mine, or challenges the very fiber of my existence (and no I wouldn't say a recipe for soba noddles should normally provide such a life challenge - but in those rare human cases of single celled exsistence I could see how something so "different" might be frightening or enraging).  You really have shown us 'pussies' a thing or two, and for that I am thankful! My life is now more enriched and elevated by your exlimation of defiance.  Well, I have to go.. it seems I have some lives to shatter with my personal and dietary choices.  Look out Texas, I'm aiming high!

comments.author: Angie's Recipes
comments.content: This is totally delicious! I wonder what's your profession? A dietitian? Angie's Recipes
